ShortDeck: The great chlorophyll fad of 1952.

Title: Make Every Piece Count
Deck: For years, the beef industry has leaned on universities to discover new cuts of steak. Don't laugh: Meat science is behind at least one breakout hit.
ShortDeck: The meat scientists on the hunt for a better cut of steak.

Title: Public Domain Disney
Deck: Disney is no friend of the public domain, but in honor of the public domain finally expanding, we wanted to appreciate Walt Disney’s contributions to it.
ShortDeck: When Walt Disney goes public domain.

Title: Let’s Save Blogging
Deck: The independent blog has been in decline for years. It doesn’t have to be that way. Here’s why you should start a blog in 2019—and host it yourself.
ShortDeck: Why you should start a blog in 2019. Really.

Title: Another Year of Tedium
Deck: The state of our Tedium in 2019 is a pivotal one if you love the idea of creating things online. Let’s talk about why—and what we can do to keep it safe.
ShortDeck: What next year has in store for the state of Tedium.

Title: Pato’s Game Theory Christmas
Deck: The tale of how a college engineering professor once used game theory to turn his holiday gift-giving into an experiment—complete with winners and losers.
ShortDeck: Lessons from a holiday experiment in game theory.

Title: Desperation-Tinged Gift Ideas
Deck: Every year, Tedium looks back and publishes a last-minute gift guide full of odd crap we found from the prior 12 months. Think we’re gonna change gears now?
ShortDeck: Tedium’s annual gift guide for people at the bottom of your list.

Title: The Bagdasarian Effect
Deck: How one man’s discovery of a clever sound effect gave us Alvin and the Chipmunks, one of the most enduring novelty musical acts of all time.
ShortDeck: The sound effect behind an iconic Christmas novelty song.

Title: The Infomercial Game
Deck: From Kevin Trudeau to Miss Cleo, infomercial schemes of the past 40 years have a lot in common with the “dark patterns” of the modern-day app economy.
ShortDeck: The “dark patterns” of modern-day apps—and vintage infomercials.

Title: The Internet, Through A Filter
Deck: As content filters re-enter the digital conversation, a look back at the internet filters of the ‘90s, and the librarian who sold the Supreme Court on them.
ShortDeck: The imprint of content filters on internet culture.

Title: When A Chain Breaks
Deck: What a blogger learned from a year of traveling to restaurants that used to be part of much larger chains before being forced to fend for themselves.
ShortDeck: Meet a guy who travels far and wide to visit broken fast-food chains.

Title: Kicking Out The Jams
Deck: The unlikely rise and amicable fall of the world’s funniest alt-rock, DIY band—The Presidents of the United States of America, who only needed five strings.

Title: Hometown Proud
Deck: The Independent Grocers Alliance (IGA), a loosely franchised grocery chain, is basically designed to allow locals to own their own stores. It's genius.
ShortDeck: A grocery store chain that lets its franchisees keep their identity.

Title: Corporate Casserole
Deck: Pondering Thanksgiving through an exceedingly corporate lens. Some of the holiday’s most important elements were brought to you by marketing and lobbying.
ShortDeck: How marketing and lobbying inspired Thanksgiving traditions.

Title: Totally Tubular
Deck: The surprising modern status of the vacuum tube, a vintage technology that continues to maintain its value and use case in a world full of transistors.

Title: Counting All Cars
Deck: Pondering the evolution of electronic tolling, the system that doesn’t slow you down even as it charges you to use it. It has roots in the theremin—sorta.

Title: His Name Was Larry
Deck: The offbeat stylings of Larry "Wild Man" Fischer, an outsider icon with ties to Frank Zappa and a wild voice who generated a cult audience against all odds.

Title: Beyond The McRib
Deck: Pondering the way that retired or obscure fast food menu items create cult followings. Had a Taco Bell Chili Cheese Burrito lately? Consider yourself lucky.

Title: Let's Overanalyze Fun
Deck: In honor of the 50th anniversary of the “Fun Size” candy bar, let’s highlight the time Mars tried to sue one of its largest competitors for using the term.

Title: Doin’ The Mash
Deck: The history of the world’s favorite Halloween carol, Bobby “Boris” Pickett’s “The Monster Mash.” Here’s how a song about dead creatures came to life.

Title: Simulated Crime
Deck: The evolution of the police training simulator, and how it directly inspired one of the most fascinating video game companies of the ‘90s.

Title: Dual-Pronged
Deck: Pondering the staple, and separately, the stapler, as they came together over time to saddle a few stitches and inspire a few tall tales.

Title: The Halloween-Industrial Complex
Deck: After the 2008 recession, commercial real estate firms had a ton of empty buildings. Fortunately, Halloween stores were ready to fill the gap—for a month.

Title: The Lazarus Libraries
Deck: What happens when “lost” films and television shows become found once again—and what that does to the work’s cultural legacy.

Title: Silicon Persistence
Deck: Decades after Silicon Graphics' heyday, its supercomputers have found themselves a new home with a small community full of enthusiasts—some just teenagers.

Title: Extreme Googling
Deck: It’s easy to forget given its size, but Google fundamentally changed our relationship with information. Two decades later, we’re still feeling the effects.

Title: Super (Small) Models
Deck: Pondering the postwar scale modeling boom, as well as where scale model enthusiasts are getting their fix today.

Title: Network Effects
Deck: For more than a decade, it's been a common sight in U.S. airports to see newsstand-style shops named for cable news networks. Why, of all things, this idea?

Title: Giving Candy A Bad Name
Deck: The surprisingly true story of Ayds, a diet suppressant candy that was incredibly successful until its name became forever associated with something else.

Title: VCR Plus Dice
Deck: From board games to stunted game systems, the many attempts to turn VHS into a platform for games ran into a big problem: There was only one way forward.

Title: Close Your Open Tabs
Deck: A case in favor of browser tab minimalism, or closing the tabs you’re not using. Sometimes, information overload has its limits.

Title: Keep Your Composure
Deck: What’s it like to be a film composer, anyway? An expert on the subject pads our knowledge of film composition, what might be cinema’s most subtle art form.

Title: Double Trouble
Deck: How a court battle involving groundbreaking disk-compression software foreshadowed Microsoft’s status as an antitrust darling.

Title: Clippy Couture
Deck: Clip art gets a bad rap as an artform, in part because it’s everywhere. Let’s give it some grudging respect by filling in some historic gaps.

Title: Trapper Keeper Contraband
Deck: The Trapper Keeper is a beacon of nostalgia, but generic branding and school rules have pushed it off to the side. Good luck finding a new one.

Title: The Ballad of Yo! Noid
Deck: In the '80s and '90s, advertisers got the idea to market products to kids through video games. The games aren't half-bad (mostly), but they're still ads.

Title: Retail’s Tech Champion
Deck: Sears and Roebuck—a firm that has seen better days—helped sell the public on computers, video games, and online services. (They made great catalogs, too.)

Title: The Podcasting Puppet Master
Deck: A puppeteer for Mystery Science Theater 3000 explains how a comedic passion—particularly Dr. Demento—led to a diverse career in podcasting and puppeteering.

Title: Nothing But Net (And Ads)
Deck: The rise of the ad-sponsored dial-up ISP offers some useful lessons on promising too much in the age of MoviePass. Good luck getting rid of that ad.

Title: Pens for Pennies
Deck: How cheap ballpoint pens, which are easy to lose and easy to make, changed the world due to their sheer disposability. They're really freaking cheap.

Title: The Sound and the Fury
Deck: How sound design—such as the iconic Indiana Jones whip noise—has come to define the film industry almost as much as all the on-screen effects.

Title: TV’s Hidden Math
Deck: How the calculus of ’80s television programming lives on into the present day—and why the Disney Channel always seems to cancel shows after 65 episodes.

Title: Click, Clack
Deck: The famed mechanical keyboard switch manufacturer Cherry has been around since the 1950s—but it's only been defined by keyboard switches in the past decade.

Title: Command Line
Deck: Nearly 40 years ago, DOS reshaped computing on the IBM PC. These days, nostalgia for that era—and a dose of fresh creativity—is keeping its legacy alive.

Title: The Agony Of Repeat
Deck: The tale of a guy who became famous for falling down once, only to have that fall replayed every single week on a legendary American TV show.

Title: Still Grasping At Straws
Deck: Businesses and cities are ditching the plastic straw, the ultimate commodity object. But the shift is controversial, and alternatives don’t come cheap.

Title: The Internet's Final Frontier
Deck: Pondering the nature of digital connectivity in the one room nobody wants to consider internet access in, even though we use it all the time: The restroom.

Title: The Fourth Of Why
Deck: Why is America’s Independence Day celebrated on July 4, despite strong evidence the independence took place on a different day?

Title: Members Only
Deck: Pondering the surprising number of musical acts that have official members that don’t actually play an instrument or sing. You know, like Coldplay.

Title: That '70s Interactive TV
Deck: The story of Columbus, Ohio’s own QUBE Interactive Television, which—beyond breaking ground for cable TV—was social media for the ’70s, for good and bad.

Title: One Frame At A Time
Deck: A long time ago in an encoding standard not so far away, an early 'net user tried to remake “Star Wars” in ASCII art form. He got further than you’d guess.

Title: The Toy That Talked Back
Deck: Four decades ago, the Speak & Spell came about, and the result was Texas Instruments’ greatest gadget and a pop-culture icon.

Title: Absolutely Brilliant!
Deck: The British company Codemasters, best known for the Game Genie, didn’t let a pesky lack of license get in the way of creating some of the NES’ best games.

Title: Flexible Noise
Deck: The history of flexi discs, the cheap alternative to vinyl records that was once a marketer’s dream material and an unusual Cold War workaround.

Title: With ARM Wide Open
Deck: The story of ARM Holdings, one of our most important tech companies, is full of sheer luck, happy accidents, and a faded British computing icon.

Title: Hooked On Velcro
Deck: How Velcro became one of the most important inventions of the 20th century, despite simultaneously gaining an unfashionable reputation.

Title: The Same Name Game
Deck: It’s not every day you watch a movie in which you share the same name as the lead character. I did, and it was a supremely dissonant experience.

Title: Robotic, But Lovable
Deck: Alexa’s Interface is treated as revolutionary, but you might be surprised to learn of your favorite opinionated cylinder’s predecessors from the mid-1980s.

Title: Window Dressing
Deck: When macOS was still OS X, some Windows users weren't afraid to remake their desktops in Apple's vision. It was the ultimate case of imitation and flattery.

Title: Nintendo Still Rocks
Deck: How music from the 8-bit video game era has inspired an entire generation of modern musicians and created new musical genres.

Title: The Chinese Robocall Blues
Deck: Like spam messages, robocalls aim for the broadest possible audience in an effort to get someone, anyone, with its scam. And both are annoying as heck, too.

Title: Make Some Noise
Deck: Sound cards like the Creative Sound Blaster were the missing element that computers needed to take on multimedia. Then, they faded from view. Here's why.

Title: They Steal Horses, Don’t They?
Deck: Discussing the rise of organizations that fought against a very specific type of crime: The theft of horses. However, that wasn’t all they were doing.

Title: How To Make A Wrestler Mad
Deck: Wrestling is a sport that you either know a lot about, or you know nothing. But even if you know nothing, you should still know about the Montreal Screwjob.

Title: Ink-Stained Pixels
Deck: The Kindle and the Nook have defined the eBook, but there are literally decades of prior art for this device—an idea many readers still haven’t warmed to.

Title: It’s Not HBO, It’s UHF
Deck: The quickly forgotten phenomenon of scrambled television stations that ran over the air on UHF signals.  Not everyone had cable TV at first.

Title: Going Through The Motions
Deck: The evolution of the robotic arm, a product invented in the U.S. that came to define modern factories around the world. It wasn't an easy sell in America.

Title: The Oracle That Spoke Too Soon
Deck: Oracle CEO Larry Ellison sold the tech world on the Network Computer, a machine designed to kill the PC’s dominance. The problem? It was 15 years too early.

Title: Not Just Nostalgia
Deck: The strange and wonderful world of homebrew games for the original Nintendo Entertainment System. Yes, new games are still being made three decades later.

Title: The Case Of The Missing Channel
Deck: The cable channel Genesis StoryTime aired in numerous homes in the U.S. and Canada. Yet few records of it exist online. Here's our attempt to fix that.

Title: Tales From The Minibar
Deck: The hotel minibar was an exciting and interesting new direction for hotels at first. But it’s since declined. Is a lack of new minibar ideas to blame?

Title: It’s New To You
Deck: The story of FuncoLand, the retailer that made the used video game market a thing—and how GameStop, which bought Funco, sort of bastardized that mission.

Title: An Institute You Can’t Disparage
Deck: How an activist named Terry Rakolta tried—and failed—to convince Middle America to stop watching “Married … With Children.” She might have saved Fox.

Title: Please Clap
Deck: The tale of The Clapper, a device that introduced millions of people to the idea of simple home automation. Would we have Alexa without it?

Title: Drip And Drive
Deck: Have you donated blood lately? Maybe you'll get inspired by reading the history of how we got modern blood donation, including (of course) the bloodmobile.

Title: New Wave Titans
Deck: How Oingo Boingo, which began as a theatre troupe, forged an endearing legacy and launched the career of one of the most popular film composers of our time.

Title: Straight Flush
Deck: The story of Uncle John’s Bathroom Reader, the greatest book series of all time that targets a uniquely captive audience. The series turns 30 this year.

Title: The Suburban Dictionary
Deck: How the sniglet took over, to the point where people use sniglets without realizing it. Sniglets don't appear in the dictionary, but they probably should.

Title: The Polyphonic Screed
Deck: The evolution of the modern cell phone ringtone—and the Ukrainian guy who wants to give Apple’s default noises a refresh.

Title: Leavin’ The Light On
Deck: The strange, fascinating career of Tom Bodett, who parlayed NPR radio essays into the longest-running spokesperson gig around. Not that it’s all he does.

Title: Consumer Conflict
Deck: From literary advocacy to union battles to communism claims, the origin story of the organization that publishes Consumer Reports kind of has it all.

Title: Fall Of Voodoo
Deck: In a few short years, the graphics card company 3Dfx Interactive provided a polygon-laden shock to the PC world—then fell apart, fast. What happened?

Title: A Distinguished Panel
Deck: The panel show, an icon of early television, was a purely American invention, yet somehow it's become deeply associated with modern British TV. Here's why.

Title: Ban The Box
Deck: The defining debate of the early compact disc era centered around the longbox, a wasteful form of packaging pushed by retailers and paper manufacturers.

Title: Oh? Haven’t You Heard?
Deck: How a single novelty song capture the public imagination, influenced punk rock and became a cultural institution. Yes, bird is, in fact, the word.

Title: Primitive Streaming Gods
Deck: Lessons from the music industry’s initial consumer-hostile reaction to the Napster saga. Going from $16 CDs to unlimited streaming is really hard.

Title: How's Your Soldering Technique?
Deck: The story of solder, the unsung hero of the digital revolution that benefits from a low melting point. It’s what keeps the circuits attached to the silicon.

Title: The Worst Part Of Waking Up
Deck: As our alarms went from analog to digital, the noises they made became a lot more abrasive. Here's the story of the technology behind your alarm clock.

Title: Dots Vs. Pixels
Deck: Two tales of resolution, only one of which involves screens. Do you know your dots per inch from your pixels per inch? Let's break down the difference.

Title: The Gift Of Abstraction
Deck: Pondering why the electronic gift card, which is newer than you think, took over the retail industry so quickly. Who had it first, anyway?

Title: Your Position, Triangulated
Deck: The evolution of the global positioning system, the greatest non-internet idea to come out of the Space Race, and why the military initially hobbled it.

Title: Biography, Unauthorized
Deck: An unauthorized look at the master of the unauthorized biography, whose name is not Michael Wolff, as it turns out. Meet Kitty Kelley.

Title: You've Been Warned
Deck: We pass by all sorts of crazy warning signs every single day—including police tape, wet floor signs, and crazy road warnings. But do they actually connect?

Title: There’s Always Next Year
Deck: The state of our Tedium in 2018 looks kind of a lot like 2017, for better or worse. Let’s take a deep breath, everyone, and hope for the best.

Title: The New Millennium Blues
Deck: The pop-culture panic leading up to the year 2000. Did all the Y2K TV movies, musical parodies, and animated homages make the problem worse?

Title: Fake Elf News
Deck: Back in 1999, the viral game Elf Bowling gained an unfounded, false reputation as a piece of malware and spyware. It was viral, but it wasn’t a virus.
ShortDeck: How Elf Bowling gained a false reputation as malware.

Title: Gifts For Total Strangers
Deck: This year’s Tedium gift guide—designed for people you’re not particularly close to—is full of ideas perfect for alienating yourself with loved ones.

Title: What The Hellmann
Deck: The hidden stories behind some of the sauces you eat every single day, from a confessed overuser of sauce. You are entitled to a little more, by the way.

Title: Sweating the Ugly Truth
Deck: The history of the sweater—along with the tale of how a Vancouver house party made the ugly Christmas sweater into the pinnacle of modern ironic taste.

Title: Trimmed For Space
Deck: As the newspaper industry contracted, so too did the furniture and the newsprint. Let's check out the first victims of the digital revolution.

Title: Our Next Annoying National Upgrade
Deck: Nine years ago, the federal government painfully pushed the public into the arms of digital TV. Soon enough, we could be making that upgrade all over again.

Title: Sharper Pixels
Deck: The push for pixel perfection at the heart of the enthusiast retro movement—and the company that wants those pixels to look better than you remember.

Title: Buy, Don’t Rent
Deck: How the rent-to-own retail model, exemplified by Rent-a-Center, evolved from a mainstream model in the U.K. to one widely seen as predatory in the U.S.

Title: Flash Forward
Deck: CompactFlash, the first dedicated flash memory card format in wide use, was a turning point for computing—as well as a format with surprising resilience.
ShortDeck: The many innovations that gave us flash memory.

Title: Smashing Potatoes
Deck: Mashed potatoes have a long, drawn-out history—especially, ironically, in instant form. Guess the recipe for the Thanksgiving icon is harder than it looks.

Title: Rock On Chicago
Deck: The larger than life and times of Chicago artist/musician Wesley Willis—as well as the deeper inspirations behind the artistic output that defined his life.

Title: Google’s Zombie
Deck: Why FeedBurner, a service that Google once bought for $100 million, has become the one service it literally can’t kill. Here's why the service lingers.

Title: Hide And Seek
Deck: For a while, hidden tracks were everywhere, especially during the CD era. But thanks to streaming music, there’s nowhere to put them. Is that good or bad?

Title: One Bumpy Ride
Deck: The story of how asphalt came to define our highways, and why potholes are such a pain. The problem? Nobody wants to spend money on preventing potholes.

Title: Out Of Order
Deck: Why aren’t area codes laid out in a seemingly logical way, like ZIP Codes are? Part of the answer can be found in the rotary dial of early telephones.

Title: I’ll Do Something Innovative When I Die
Deck: How could innovative ideas improve funerals and final resting places? It’s a question not being asked enough. Let’s take a dive into funeral technology.

Title: When Copyright Goes Copywrong
Deck: The rigid nature of copyright law during the early years of the film industry created a surprisingly robust cottage industry around public domain films.

Title: Serious Cornhole
Deck: You might think of cornhole as a lighthearted lawn game, but it actually has a professional league, a family of stars, and some budding momentum. Really.

Title: Picking Up The Slack
Deck: Internet Relay Chat beat Slack to real-time chat by decades and helped define much of our early online culture, yet way more people use Slack. Why is that?

Title: Flying Patents
Deck: How the unidentified flying object inspired a flurry of flying saucer patents globally—and how one guy invented his flying saucer years before anyone else.

Title: Encoded, Decoded
Deck: How Usenet—a protocol intended for conversations—was forever changed once the public figured out you could transfer binary files through it.

Title: A Eulogy for Eudora
Deck: The early graphical client Eudora was how people checked their email in the ’90s. But in the end, only the power users stuck around. Here’s what you missed.

Title: Maximum Cargo
Deck: Sometimes the overhead bin just isn’t enough. Learn more about combi planes, nonstandard types of aircraft that mix passenger seating with cargo shipping.

Title: An Early Touchpoint
Deck: How the graphics tablet, most notably produced by Japanese firm Wacom, helped shape our multitouch-friendly world—even if that shaping took a little while.

Title: Stable Rent
Deck: What it's like to keep and maintain a pet horse in New York City, the largest city in the U.S., in 2017. As it turns out, it's not particularly cheap.

Title: The Knockoff Game
Deck: How the success of the Game Boy inspired a variety of rip-off consoles sold under a variety of bizarre corporate structures. This goes deeper than the Lynx.

Title: We're Running Out of Widgets
Deck: What do Barnes & Noble, Radio Shack, and Blockbuster have in common? Simple: Their flawed business models relied on selling physical objects in stores.

Title: Why Aren't You Wearing Corduroy?
Deck: How corduroy, a piece of fabric with ancient ties that was built for the working-class, became really friggin' trendy all over again.

Title: The Man With 400 Albums
Deck: The tale of R. Stevie Moore, perhaps the most prolific musician that the world has ever seen. So why haven't you heard of him?

Title: Let’s Lock Information Down
Deck: DRM, one of the internet’s dark arts, was already in the works—complete with epic patents—years before the existence of Napster gave it a business case.

Title: Do You Copy?
Deck: How the lineage of the walkie-talkie reaches from World War II to the modern cell phone. Walkie-talkies even inspired a major cell phone network.

Title: Get Yourself A Treat
Deck: How movie theaters nudged film-goers out of their seats with short clips designed around the hard sell.

Title: Sing Your Heart Out
Deck: From 8-Track to Laserdisc to CD+G to ISDN lines to YouTube, the different technologies that made karaoke possible. (Alcohol helps, too.)

Title: The Back of the Napkin
Deck: From soft dough to paper, the world’s definition of a napkin has evolved significantly over the past couple thousand years. (It’s currently evolving again.)

Title: Bend, Don’t Break
Deck: When new innovations in rubber and plastic hit during the 19th and 20th centuries, hair combs usually had them first—especially in unbreakable form.

Title: How To Checkmate Yourself
Deck: The parlor games hosted by Yahoo! once represented some of the internet’s best efforts at interactivity. But that didn’t last. Here’s how Yahoo! Games lost.

Title: When Tech Hit Retail
Deck: Point-of-sale systems dramatically modernized supply chains and allowed consumers to go cashless, but they were not without their learning curves.

Title: Who’s Who? Who Cares
Deck: How the “Who’s Who” concept of reference books devolved from a genuinely useful idea into a very costly form of vanity publishing.

Title: Who Killed The Encyclopedia?
Deck: The fast demise of the physical encyclopedia came about thanks to an upstart publisher, an indecisive giant, and the world’s biggest software company.

Title: When Time Became Money
Deck: The story of the calculagraph—a vintage device that helped pool halls, workplaces, and telephone operators track time—and the phrase that helped inspire it.

Title: Cheese, American Style
Deck: Despite cheese existing long before the U.S. did, it has come to define American food culture globally—and not just because of American cheese. Why is that?

Title: The Internet On Dead Trees
Deck: Books and periodicals about the internet were a curious phenomenon—in no small part because they frequently pandered to the largest possible audience.

Title: More Dialing, More Weirdness
Deck: There are lots more weird phone numbers out there—and some of them have pretty fascinating stories. Read on to learn more about the vintage phone system.

Title: Burrowing A Gopher Hole
Deck: The Gopher protocol isn't supported by the modern web basically at all, but despite this, it lingers on, a quarter century from its peak. Here's how.

Title: In Case Of Emergency
Deck: The nationwide roll-out of the 911 system was a difficult endeavor, and one that only made it past the finish line thanks to a charitable foundation.

Title: Life In Four Colors
Deck: Somehow CGA graphics, the IBM PC’s first take on color, haven’t completely faded into history. But those four colors inspire a whole lot of nostalgia.

Title: A Window Into Windex
Deck: From cleaning solutions to spray nozzles, the technology that made cleaning windows possible. And where did the word squeegee come from, anyway?

Title: Back To The Shack
Deck: RadioShack’s recent troubles might best be reflected by the recent auction of its corporate history—an auction that is actually full of interesting gadgets.

Title: Pictures For Everyone
Deck: The reason we’re so crazy about photos in the smartphone era is in no small part because of early innovations that brought photo processing to the masses.

Title: Universal Themes
Deck: The universal remote control, love it or hate it, made our lives just a little bit simpler starting in the ‘80s. It's not as good as it could be. That's OK.

Title: Out Of Our League
Deck: Is there room for another mainstream sports league? Despite lots of attempts over the years to introduce new pro sports, the answer appears to be no.

Title: 86’ed
Deck: Intel's processor business was massive, but a lengthy legal battle with a former business partner exposed a major flaw in its CPU designs—a trademark flaw.

Title: Building Blocks, Literally
Deck: Perhaps alphabet blocks seem like an obvious idea now, but it took a lot of foundation to build up that pretty good idea into something incredibly common.

Title: The Invisible Puzzle
Deck: Wireless spectrum is scarce, and while mobile providers have made a sport of grabbing as much as they can, the fact is, allocating it has always been hard.

Title: How The Cookie Crumbles
Deck: Why did Hydrox cookies lose out to Oreo despite being the first cookie to market? Long story short: The name seemed like a better idea 100 years ago.

Title: Clone Wars
Deck: The Apple II computer didn't attract as many clones as the IBM PC, but the clone-makers the machine did attract often had pretty interesting second acts.

Title: Secretly Made With Meat
Deck: Products you probably use all the time, from fabric softeners to condoms, use unexpected animal byproducts. But not Guinness anymore, fortunately.

Title: The Keys To Success
Deck: A lot of early video game consoles secretly wanted to be home computers, too: Their makers either sold keyboard add-ons or failed miserably in the process.

Title: Why Are Trains Always Late?
Deck: Despite its best efforts, Amtrak always seems like it has hugely delayed arrivals. One possible reason for that? It doesn't own most of the tracks.

Title: Operating In Obscurity
Deck: It ain’t just about Windows, macOS, or Linux. Also-ran or fairly obscure operating systems, like OS/2, are everywhere—in some cases, hiding under your nose.

Title: CMYK All The Way
Deck: How mass-production printing technology, starting with the lithograph, was pushed forward thanks to a growing interest in color.

Title: Lickety Split
Deck: Why lick-on adhesives on letters maintain a market presence, despite being seemingly old-hat. (Well, except for stamps. We kinda gave up on ‘em there.)

Title: Boom, Roasted
Deck: Not every fast food chain is going to be a success. And often, the best you can hope for is the kind of revival Kenny Rogers Roasters is having in Asia.

Title: Seek And Spell
Deck: Teaching computers to read was one of the 20th century's great challenges. At first, the secret to optical character recognition was purpose-built type.

Title: Stuck On You
Deck: Suction cups are the tiniest little vacuums around, and there’s one U.S. company that sells millions of them every single year. Here’s how they caught on.

Title: Frickin' Laser Beams
Deck: The tale of Science Faction, a company that brought massive laser light shows to venues around the world. They blew a lot of minds along the way.

Title: It’s Not Styrofoam
Deck: Once seen as an incredibly innovative, lightweight material, expanded polystyrene foam is now just a big problem—in part because it’s so hard to recycle.

Title: Reverse-Engineering The Industry
Deck: Third-party developers weren't always quite so revered in the video game industry, but a pair of legal decisions helped them earn their place at the table.

Title: Your Code Is Junky
Deck: FrontPage tried to solve an important problem in the early-internet era—the idea of making web design accessible to mere mortals—but the code wasn't so hot.

Title: Lemony Fresh
Deck: Lemon juice has long come in containers shaped like lemons. In the U.K., the containers hold an important legacy—both with pancakes and the legal system.

Title: No Comment
Deck: The audio commentary track, a staple of films on optical media, may not last into the age of streaming. Is it a victim of indifference by Netflix?

Title: Delivered To Your Door
Deck: The internet made monthly subscription boxes cool, but the roots of this business model can be found in decisions made in the 19th and early 20th centuries.

Title: We’re Gunning For IBM
Deck: The minicomputer maker Wang Laboratories ran an ad on the Super Bowl long before Apple did. So why did the company and its minicomputers become a footnote?
